awd_abstract_narration:
This project is devoted to study of tensor categories, which are abstract mathematical objects expressing an intuitive notion of symmetry in precise mathematical language. These objects naturally appear in various areas of mathematics.  In addition, tensor categories are relevant to some areas of physics, such as condensed matter physics, where some special types of tensor categories are used to describe anyons -- quasi-particles that are governed by statistics different from bosonic or fermionic type.  Tensor categories also appear in theoretical computer science as a framework for topological quantum computation, one potential framework for design of a quantum computer. 

The aim of this project is to advance knowledge about tensor categories.  The project addresses the following areas: development of general theory with an eye on specific classification theorems; applications of general theory of tensor categories to other areas of mathematics; and search for new interesting examples of tensor categories.  More specifically, the work includes the following projects: study of semisimple tensor categories with specific Grothendieck rings; study of possible actions (or, equivalently, of module categories) of well-known tensor categories constructed via the Wess-Zumino-Witten model; study of symmetric tensor categories in positive characteristic; search for new examples of tensor categories using theory of Kazhdan-Lusztig cells and Soergel bimodules; and search for applications of tensor categories in the theory of vertex algebras and finite W-algebras.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project was devoted to theoretical study of abstract algebraic objects called tensor categories. These objects appear in various areas of mathematics but are also relevant to some questions in theoretical physics (such as conformal field theory and condensed state theory especially theory of anyons) and theoretical computer science (topological quantum computing). One reason to study these objects is because they provide a mathematical framework for some physical models describing systems of interacting particles or quasi-particles which can collide and transform to other particles (this framework is most relevant for so called gapped systems where particles behave in a "topological" way).

The outcomes of this project are a number of theorems (published in suitable mathematical journals) describing some structural properties of tensor categories under suitable assumptions. A big portion of this project was devoted to the study of symmetric tensor categories over fields of positive characteristic extending remarkable results of P.Deligne on such categories over fields of characteristic zero. Despite the fact that such categories can't appear in the description of physical objects (since mathematics relevant to physics is done over the field of complex numbers which is of characteristic zero), there are some very interesting connections with physics. For instance the major player in this story is so called Verlinde category which is named after well known physicist E.Verlinde since it is very closed to a similar object defined over the complex numbers (and relevant to physics). One of the main goals of this line of research is to show that many symmetric tensor categories can be described in terms of "group theory" in Verlinde category. Some of the most important outcomes of this project is a theorem saying that this indeed the case under suitable assumptions (for so called "Frobenius exact" categories) and a conjecture describing what happens under more general assumptions (this required a construction of new "higher" Verlinde categories).

Another part of the project was study of fusion categories and modular tensor categories over the field of complex numbers (and thus potentially relevant to physics). We proved some restrictions on numerical invariants of such objects, gave a mathematical treatment of the phenomenon of level rank duality (in the special case of symplectic groups), and proved some new results on modular tensor categories related with the theory of finite groups. 


Last Modified: 10/28/2022
Modified by: Viktor Ostrik
